job_title: Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: -Benefits -Snacks -Catering -Nice people, good culture, diverse -Clean lab space
cons: - Similar to academic labs, works like it too - Low compensation for those who actually do the science compared to higher ups who have never stepped into the lab - Junior scientists are not incentivized to stay - Higher ups demonstrate clear favoritism

review_title: Fantastic culture, benefits, scientific exposure and mentorship
pros: I really enjoyed working here overall. It has a great culture, community feeling, people are very intrinsically motivated and passionate for their jobs, and there's a constant stream of visiting scientists and new ideas, new projects.
cons:
It's clearly intended as a stop over for people on their way to grad school. There isn't a well established path for growth within the organization, either for engineers or other departments. I think this is by design.

I was there for 2 years and saw exactly one person receive a substantive promotion that increased their responsibilities, in the operations department.

Pay is low relative to Bay Area standards but off the charts amazing for academic standards.

If they put you on a performance improvement plan then don't bother trying to improve, it's just a paper trail to justify firing you a few months later. When they do fire you, they will tell everyone else you "voluntarily resigned". 

It's an awesome academic and research culture with a surprisingly antagonistic and somewhat toxic HR department.

pros: Lot of collaborative spirit. Young enthusiastic people
cons: High turnover Salary is not competitive with industry Promotions are not easy

job_title: Research Associate I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Cool research, access to new technology, great lab facility
cons: No opportunity for promotion/career advancement as an RA. RAs are generally overworked, underpaid, and underappreciated.

pros: Work-life balance, hands-off management (depending on your team), and mostly down-to-earth coworkers
cons: Can't think of any to be honest.

review_title: Terrible place for your mental health
pros: The lab managers keep all of the workspaces in great shape.
cons: Research Associates are overworked and underpaid compared to other RA positions with comparable responsibilities. Group leaders do not have proper management training. Very palpable unconscious bias against women and people of color. Biohub definitely focuses more on science than their people. A lot of the cultural issues have been there since day one and have been brought up time and time again but leaders do not prioritize them enough. Biohub is able to get away with it because they get a fresh batch of new grads to overwork each year.

review_title: Learning Opportunities Great, Clouded By Poor Management
pros: 1) manager are encouraging of development within role 2) many people out of college or grad school are taken in 3) open discussion on diversity 4) online and instrumental resources 5) ease of moving between teams at organization (eg. lab to data scientist, one team to another)
cons: 1) operations, lab management, and data science is understaffed 2) managers ask for too many hours of their employees for the pay 3) higher up leaders are interested in personal agendas and fame 4) people can be passive aggressive and sensitive about every topic and are overly politically correct 5) generally people don't take off as much vacation because we have to discuss taking vacation without our bosses

review_title: few opportunities for promotion, work time is too much for pay, nice people
pros: the organization is very nice in it's willingness to hire people who are fresh and help them gain experience, the biohub also has a good culture around take time off and a few perks that stem from the fact that Mark Zuckerberg funds the place (better benefits than academic, snacks, more money, etc)
cons: the organization has a strict rule against applying to grants because of its partnerships with local universities, so as a PI there is limited growth for budget if the organization doesn't increase it (which can be difficult), the organization also asks for too much time of its scientists and research associations and doesn't have a standardized system to give feedback to team members or managers such that managers and team members continue inappropriate behavior, i was actually offended by an employee and after asking him to stop offending me, he retaliated and stopped talking to me even going as far as slamming a door to my face, after communicating to HR about the situation, they suggested i take the responsibility of advocating for myself and HR was unwilling to include a discussion on how to receive feedback when being told you are saying something offense, instead maintaining a culture in it is the responsibility of the individual that is offended or overworked handle the situation, leaders form the group leaders themselves to the chief scientific officer are not in favor of raises or promotions when they can pay workers less for the same salary which has resulted in a high turnover rate

review_title: Great research institution for biomedical research
pros:
1. Exciting projects
2. Friendly and capable colleagues
3. Great benefit
cons:
1. Communication is not efficient
2. Career development plan is unclear

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Smart elite talented colleagues.
State of the art instruments and facilities.
cons: I wish there were more opportunities for intrapreneurship.

review_title: Great science- poor plan of career advancement
pros: Group leaders, scientists, and RAs are very talented and passionate. You feel that you're really at the frontline of scientific discovery.
cons:
Career development tracks might as well be non-existent. Employees at the lower end of the hierarchy (research associates) frequently express burn out. Despite doing all the hard work, their contributions are often underrepresented and unappreciated.

The culture is very conceited. Vocal groups in the organization are really on the high horse about politics, political-correctness, and social mission of the organization. It is as if they are somehow unaware that we're all getting paid by Mark Zuckerberg. Leadership tends to turn a blind eye to significant problems in the management, and are mostly focused on hyping the org.

review_title: RAs: Enjoy your mental health? The Biohub is not for you
pros: amazing science, beautiful building and state of the art labs
cons:
some of this is very team dependent, so take my review with a grain of salt. that being said, my conversations with other RAs have illustrated that burnout is rampant. expect to be treated as an experienced graduate student, without the proper mentorship or financial compensation. i think the main issue comes down to having young team leaders that have no actual management skills, so you end up with an over-achieving boss who does not know the value of positive feedback and is mostly trying to use you for your skills/time/youthful energy so that they can publish papers and make their bosses happy.
perhaps if we got paid more than ~60k it might be worth it!

pros: Great work environment, everyone is super nice and helpful.
cons: Not too many cons, loved my time there.

pros:
- Brilliant coworkers that are really nice and will try to help you develop skills
- Exposure to cutting edge research projects
- Snacks, drinks, occasional catering
cons:
- Managers are not good at managing people
- No career guidance or development; everyone assumes you will be going to grad school 
- Long hours for lab personnel

job_title: Research Associate I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Cutting-edge technology, abundant resources, scientifically prestigious
cons: Can be a bit political and corporate

pros:
Interesting research, including basic science
Great group of people working there
Energetic feel
cons: Pay is incredibly low.  Company said they were doing a salary review since this came back as a concern from the company-wide survey. They said they did a salary review but I don't think it helped. At least it didn't help me.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great scientific staff, topics, and facilities.
cons: Management is messy. Unclear how HR evaluates employees and their works.

review_title: Fantastic place to learn and grow
pros: Brilliant scientific leaders, willingness to teach junior scientists, access to world class facilities
cons: Disorganized management and unclear long term vision
